1-chunk_32_-7917464071226351761.chunk_text: Image 9 blob:http://localhost/558ddb7306c65a878fbe11fa4df0b8cf) The rodmap for an ASEAN Community 2009 2015 was declared by the leaders in 2009. The ASEAN Community, anchored on three community pillars: Political Security Community, Economic Community, Socio Cultural Community was launched in 2015. The ASEAN 2025: Forging Ahead Together was introduced in 2015 as a Post 2015 Vision. It comprises the ASEAN Community Vision 2025, the ASEAN Political Security Community Blueprint 2025, the ASEAN Economic Community Blueprint 2025 and the ASEAN Socio Cultural Community Blueprint 2025 Read More https://asean.org/our-communities/)

! Image 13 blob:http://localhost/417f09174c1e44baf6ce8e4e4b2f3d85) The Association of Southeast Asian Nations, or ASEAN, was established on 8 August 1967 in Bangkok, Thailand, with the signing of the ASEAN Declaration Bangkok Declaration by the Founding Fathers of ASEAN: Indonesia, Malaysia, Philippines, Singapore and Thailand. Brunei Darussalam joined ASEAN on 7 January 1984, followed by Viet Nam on 28 July 1995, Lao PDR and Myanmar on 23 July 1997, and Cambodia on 30 April 1999, making up what is today the ten Member States of ASEAN. Read More https://asean.org/about-us/)

1-chunk_64_8246575199954687632.chunk_text:
Image 21 blob:http://localhost/e8a57f4972516a1d3218894eabc89576) https://asean.org/) Highlight on Singapore’s Homepage Home ❭ https://asean.org/) Highlight on Singapore’s Homepage
! Image 23 https://asean.org/wp-content/uploads/2021/08/ASEANFlagWeb_default-3.jpg)

1-chunk_65_-5969395532611561738.chunk_text: Image 23 https://asean.org/wp-content/uploads/2021/08/ASEANFlagWeb_default-3.jpg) Highlight on Singapore’s Homepage Policies Singapore’s economic policy is to promote the creation of national wealth through sustained and stable economic growth.

1-chunk_66_7923922213109352774.chunk_text: Singapore’s economic policy is to promote the creation of national wealth through sustained and stable economic growth. A guiding principle of economic policy is the free market system, that is, to allow market forces to determine the pattern of trade. The Singapore Government seeks to ensure that the trading system is open and transparent. Customs and trade documentation procedures are streamlined for smooth flow of goods in and out of Singapore.

1-chunk_67_1539671408316087213.chunk_text: Customs and trade documentation procedures are streamlined for smooth flow of goods in and out of Singapore. Singapore does not have any sector specific policies or trade instruments to promote exports. The private sector is encouraged to play a leading role in economic development while the Government provides an environment conducive for private sector business activities. Fiscal policy is aimed at supporting the private sector in economic development.

1-chunk_68_2905056959325179267.chunk_text: Fiscal policy is aimed at supporting the private sector in economic development. On the revenue side, the objective is to raise sufficient revenue to finance expenditure while maintaining a competitive tax structure. The implementation of the Goods and Services Tax from April 1994 was to enhance competitiveness of Singapore’s tax structure. On the expenditure side, efforts are made to maintain a small and efficient public sector to release maximum financial and manpower resources to the private sector.

1-chunk_69_6451707887236913767.chunk_text: On the expenditure side, efforts are made to maintain a small and efficient public sector to release maximum financial and manpower resources to the private sector. Hence, certain operations are being privatised to give them greater autonomy to be run according to commercial practices. This includes telecommunications, broadcasting, electricity and gas etc. The privatization programme in Singapore was undertaken to achieve the following objectives:

1-chunk_70_4176956293670560702.chunk_text: The privatization programme in Singapore was undertaken to achieve the following objectives: 1. to withdraw from commercial activities which no longer need to be undertaken by the public sector; 2.

1-chunk_71_-2936974523750184697.chunk_text: 2. to add breadth and depth to the Singapore stock market by the flotation of government linked companies and statutory boards and through secondary distribution of government owned shares; 3. to avoid or reduce competition with the private sector;

1-chunk_72_-5518459425299520511.chunk_text: to avoid or reduce competition with the private sector; 4. to improve efficiency of services through market discipline; and 5.

1-chunk_73_-7669910956043046810.chunk_text: 5. to increase the assets of Singaporeans through share ownership in the privatised companies. Opportunities Singapore’s economic achievement has its origin in trade.

1-chunk_74_7745992945238440530.chunk_text: Singapore’s economic achievement has its origin in trade. Long before its independence, Singapore has served as a port of call between the East and the West. This strategic link is more important now than ever before with the globalization of economies and increasing economic inter depedence. Accelerated economic development in Asia will emphasize Singapore’s role as a gateway to the region.

1-chunk_75_-4316134190394837401.chunk_text: Accelerated economic development in Asia will emphasize Singapore’s role as a gateway to the region. The key to Singapore’s flourishing international trade has been its free trade policy. Virtually all goods enter Singapore duty free. Singapore’s political stability, excellent business infrastructure, strategic location, sound legal framework, work class financial services and a pro business approach have attracted many internation companies to do business with Singapore and to use Singapore as a base for their regional expansion.

1-chunk_76_-3895806225461701244.chunk_text: Singapore’s political stability, excellent business infrastructure, strategic location, sound legal framework, work class financial services and a pro business approach have attracted many internation companies to do business with Singapore and to use Singapore as a base for their regional expansion. Singapore’s Web site offers information on business and trade opportunities in Singapore. This includes company listings, calendar of trade events, fairs and conventions. Statistics

1-chunk_77_-738445275383853989.chunk_text: Statistics Comprehensive statistics on various aspects of Singapore are listed in the Singapore Web site. Demographic statistics and economic and social indicators are compiled by the Department of Statistics. The Singapore Trade Statistics is published monthly by the Singapore Trade Development Board.

1-chunk_78_7925372438339020577.chunk_text: The Singapore Trade Statistics is published monthly by the Singapore Trade Development Board. Imports and exports are listed by country of origin and by destination. Summary time series trade statistics is also available. Directories

1-chunk_79_-5370847196705510376.chunk_text: Directories The Singapore Web site provides a comprehensive listings of Singapore’s industries, companies, government bodies and trade associations. The data are provided by the Singapore Government, the Trade Development Board and by various other organisations. Also included is a directory of Web sites containing useful business information in Singapore.

1-chunk_80_-7438230511286574502.chunk_text: Also included is a directory of Web sites containing useful business information in Singapore. For further information on any of the above topics, you may wish to go to Singapore Web Server The ASEAN Secretariat 70A Jalan Sisingamangaraja

2-chunk_0_1300211839039764109.chunk_text:
Title: SkillsFuture Singapore Guide 2025: Credits, Grants & Courses URL Source: https://asktraining.edu.sg/what-is-skillsfuture-singapore-an-essential-guide-2024 Published Time: 2024 07 18T00:00:00 08:00 Markdown Content:
!

2-chunk_1_-6547019266430229064.chunk_text:
Markdown Content:
! Image 1: blog header https://asktraining.com.sg/wp-content/uploads/2024/07/What-is-SkillsFuture_header-1.png) SkillsFuture Singapore SSG Overview The world of work is constantly evolving.

2-chunk_2_-4610910659356957855.chunk_text: The world of work is constantly evolving. New technologies emerge, industries shift, and the skills employers seek are constantly changing. Whether you’re a mid career professional looking to stay relevant, a young professional building your foundation, or an employer seeking to invest in your workforce, SSG is here to empower your future. This article provides a comprehensive guide to this nationwide initiative by the Singaporean government, highlighting the benefits, resources, and how you can utilise them to achieve your career goals.

2-chunk_3_-3081314132813926921.chunk_text: This article provides a comprehensive guide to this nationwide initiative by the Singaporean government, highlighting the benefits, resources, and how you can utilise them to achieve your career goals. The Progression of SkillsFuture Singapore What is SkillsFuture Singapore? SSG is a national movement that promotes lifelong learning and job skills enhancement for all Singaporeans.

2-chunk_4_-2158864534625651918.chunk_text: SSG is a national movement that promotes lifelong learning and job skills enhancement for all Singaporeans. It recognises the significance of workforce skills for Singapore’s continued economic success and global competitiveness. SSG offers a wide range of resources to help you adapt, grow, and thrive in the dynamic job market. In 2023 alone, SkillsFuture empowered over 520,000 individuals https://www.straitstimes.com/singapore/skillsfuture-participation-drops-in-2023-despite-increased-employer-engagement) to invest in their professional development.

2-chunk_5_2773821876298336234.chunk_text: In 2023 alone, SkillsFuture empowered over 520,000 individuals https://www.straitstimes.com/singapore/skillsfuture-participation-drops-in-2023-despite-increased-employer-engagement) to invest in their professional development. Notably, nearly 192,000 participants leveraged their SkillsFuture Credits, with a significant majority 95% utilising them for industry specific courses, demonstrating a strong focus on career oriented upskilling and reskilling. History of SkillsFuture Singapore Launched in 2015, SSG has undergone significant development over the years.

2-chunk_6_7391170921933998943.chunk_text: Launched in 2015, SSG has undergone significant development over the years. The government has introduced various policy changes and SSG initiatives to expand its reach and effectiveness. These include increased education funding, the introduction of SkillsFuture Credits, and enhanced subsidies for mid career professionals. Objectives and Target Audience

2-chunk_7_-8827570792025322206.chunk_text: Objectives and Target Audience SSG caters to a wide range of individuals, including: Mid career professionals SSG understands the challenges faced by those in the middle of their careers. The programme offers resources and financial support to help you upskill and reskill in in demand areas, keeping you competitive and opening doors to new career opportunities. Young professionals and students As you embark on your professional journey, SSG provides valuable guidance to explore career paths aligned with industry needs.

2-chunk_8_-5138495509463207369.chunk_text: Young professionals and students As you embark on your professional journey, SSG provides valuable guidance to explore career paths aligned with industry needs. You can gain foundational skills and industry exposure through SSG work study programmes, giving you a head start in your chosen field. Employers and HR professionals Investing in your employees’ job skills is an investment in your company’s future. SSG offers a range of training grants and programmes to help you develop your workforce, fostering a culture of continuous learning and innovation within your organisation.

2-chunk_9_-2883587667778512234.chunk_text: SSG offers a range of training grants and programmes to help you develop your workforce, fostering a culture of continuous learning and innovation within your organisation. By upskilling your employees, you can empower them to take on greater responsibility, potentially leading to promotions and advancements within your company. This not only benefits the individual employee but also strengthens your talent pool and improves overall company performance. Key Components of SkillsFuture Singapore

2-chunk_10_363455552614246836.chunk_text: Key Components of SkillsFuture Singapore SSG offers a diverse range of resources to support your learning journey: SkillsFuture Credits Every Singaporean aged 25 and above receives a SkillsFuture Credit https://www.skillsfuture.gov.sg/initiatives/mid-career/credit) balance to use for approved courses.

2-chunk_11_7762767503118560172.chunk_text: Every Singaporean aged 25 and above receives a SkillsFuture Credit https://www.skillsfuture.gov.sg/initiatives/mid-career/credit) balance to use for approved courses. This financial support makes skills acquisition more accessible, allowing you to invest in your professional development without breaking the bank. Additionally, from May 2024, all Singaporeans aged 40 and above will enjoy a SkillsFuture Credit https://www.myskillsfuture.gov.sg/content/portal/en/career-resources/career-resources/education-career-personal-development/SkillsFuture_Credit.html) top up of S$4,000. This is to help offset those out of pocket course fees for selected courses aligned with the current industry and employment needs.

2-chunk_12_8582022604039328879.chunk_text: This is to help offset those out of pocket course fees for selected courses aligned with the current industry and employment needs. SkillsFuture Work Study Programmes These Work Study Programmes https://www.skillsfuture.gov.sg/initiatives/students/workstudy) combine theoretical classroom learning with on the job experience, providing a unique opportunity to gain valuable industry exposure while pursuing your studies. This blend of learning allows you to apply theoretical knowledge in a practical setting, giving you a competitive edge when entering the workforce.

2-chunk_13_-1348669641821081205.chunk_text: This blend of learning allows you to apply theoretical knowledge in a practical setting, giving you a competitive edge when entering the workforce. SkillsFuture Mid Career Enhanced Subsidy Turning 40 doesn’t have to mean a career plateau. The Mid Career Enhanced Subsidy https://www.skillsfuture.gov.sg/initiatives/mid-career/enhancedsubsidy) provides additional financial support for Singaporeans aged 40 and above to undergo relevant skills training.

2-chunk_14_-4271355371801400507.chunk_text: The Mid Career Enhanced Subsidy https://www.skillsfuture.gov.sg/initiatives/mid-career/enhancedsubsidy) provides additional financial support for Singaporeans aged 40 and above to undergo relevant skills training. This government subsidy eases the financial burden of upskilling or reskilling, empowering you to make a smooth transition into new and exciting career paths. It’s important to note that the level of subsidy you receive can vary depending on the type of company you are employed by: SMEs Small and Medium Enterprises The government recognises the importance of supporting skills development within SMEs. For employees working in SMEs, the SkillsFuture Mid Career Enhanced Subsidy can cover up to 70% of the course fees for approved SSG programmes.

2-chunk_15_4768716210799501545.chunk_text: For employees working in SMEs, the SkillsFuture Mid Career Enhanced Subsidy can cover up to 70% of the course fees for approved SSG programmes. MNCs Multinational Corporations While MNCs also benefit from the SkillsFuture Mid Career Enhanced Subsidy, the subsidy level is generally lower than for SMEs. For employees working in MNCs, the subsidy typically covers up to 50% of the course fees. This tiered subsidy structure encourages companies of all sizes to invest in their employees’ professional development.

2-chunk_16_3513737175279570897.chunk_text: This tiered subsidy structure encourages companies of all sizes to invest in their employees’ professional development. For SMEs, the higher subsidy can make a significant difference in their ability to offer upskilling and reskilling opportunities to their workforce. Benefits of SkillsFuture Singapore For Each Group SSG offers a comprehensive range of benefits designed to empower individuals at all stages of their careers and organisations seeking to invest in their workforce.

2-chunk_17_-343945914419180343.chunk_text: SSG offers a comprehensive range of benefits designed to empower individuals at all stages of their careers and organisations seeking to invest in their workforce. Here’s a breakdown of the key advantages categorised by your specific needs. For Mid Career Professionals Upskilling and Reskilling Stay relevant and competitive by acquiring new in demand skills or enhancing existing ones.

2-chunk_18_1481410585456426524.chunk_text: Upskilling and Reskilling Stay relevant and competitive by acquiring new in demand skills or enhancing existing ones. SSG courses can open doors to exciting new career opportunities or upskilling opportunities within your current field. Mid Career Enhanced Subsidy Ease the financial burden of upskilling or reskilling with additional government training initiatives and educational subsidies specifically for those aged 40 and above. This subsidy allows you to invest in your professional development without derailing your budget.

2-chunk_19_4579367430177952743.chunk_text: This subsidy allows you to invest in your professional development without derailing your budget. Industry Aligned Training and Career Transition Explore courses designed to bridge the gap between your current skillset and the requirements of your target industry. With the right professional training and support, SSG can empower you to successfully transition into a new and fulfilling career path. Career Growth Obtaining industry recognised credentials through SSG programmes can make you a more valuable asset to your employer.

2-chunk_20_-1508688872379431314.chunk_text: Career Growth Obtaining industry recognised credentials through SSG programmes can make you a more valuable asset to your employer. This can lead to career progression opportunities, increased responsibility, and higher earning potential. Certifications from recognised institutions further enhance your professional credibility and marketability. When applying for jobs in a new industry, certifications demonstrate your commitment to learning and your ability to grasp new concepts.

2-chunk_21_792936812754039597.chunk_text: When applying for jobs in a new industry, certifications demonstrate your commitment to learning and your ability to grasp new concepts. This can help you stand out from other candidates with limited industry experience. Support for Lifelong Learning SSG goes beyond just providing courses. It fosters a culture of continuous learning throughout your career.

2-chunk_22_3347493404613125575.chunk_text: It fosters a culture of continuous learning throughout your career. The programme offers valuable resources and guidance to help you identify relevant learning opportunities, ensuring you stay adaptable and relevant throughout your professional journey. For Young Professionals and Students Upskilling and Reskilling Build a strong foundation for your career by acquiring essential skills aligned with industry needs.

2-chunk_23_-7753988816232200170.chunk_text: Upskilling and Reskilling Build a strong foundation for your career by acquiring essential skills aligned with industry needs. SSG offers a wide range of courses to help you explore different career paths and develop the skillset employers seek. Financial Support SkillsFuture Credits SkillsFuture Credits make acquiring the skills and knowledge you need more accessible. These credits offset course fees, allowing you to invest in your future without a significant financial outlay.

2-chunk_24_8896259834366767948.chunk_text: These credits offset course fees, allowing you to invest in your future without a significant financial outlay. Industry Aligned Training: SSG programmes ensure the skills you acquire are in high demand by employers. This increases your employability and improves your chances of landing a fulfilling job after graduation or during your early career stages. Job Placement and Employment Outcomes Some SSG programmes even offer job placement support, providing valuable assistance as you embark on your job search.

2-chunk_25_2848006238078324973.chunk_text: Job Placement and Employment Outcomes Some SSG programmes even offer job placement support, providing valuable assistance as you embark on your job search. This can include resume writing workshops, interview skills training, and even connecting you with potential employers. For Employers and HR Professionals Upskilling and Reskilling Invest in your workforce by providing them with opportunities to develop the skills and knowledge needed to excel in their roles and adapt to evolving industry demands.

2-chunk_26_-5319724927685947048.chunk_text: Upskilling and Reskilling Invest in your workforce by providing them with opportunities to develop the skills and knowledge needed to excel in their roles and adapt to evolving industry demands. SSG offers a vast array of courses to address skill gaps within your organisation and foster a culture of innovation. Financial Support Employer Grants Leverage government subsidies to offset the cost of training your employees. This allows you to invest in your workforce development programmes without straining your budget.

2-chunk_27_1851964704613570798.chunk_text: This allows you to invest in your workforce development programmes without straining your budget. Career Growth Employee Retention and Advancement Investing in your employees’ skills demonstrates your commitment to their professional development, leading to increased employee satisfaction and reduced turnover. A skilled workforce is also a more productive workforce. By upskilling your employees, you can enhance operational efficiency and drive innovation within your organisation.

2-chunk_28_-3801268430035823684.chunk_text: By upskilling your employees, you can enhance operational efficiency and drive innovation within your organisation. Economic Impact Contribute to Singapore’s continued economic success by ensuring your workforce is equipped with the latest skills and knowledge to compete in the global market. By understanding the specific benefits that SSG offers to each group, you can leverage this programme to achieve your individual or organisational goals. Image 2: infographic on the benefits of skillsfuture sg https://asktraining.com.sg/wp-content/uploads/2024/07/Benefits-of-SkillsFuture_infographic.png)

2-chunk_29_-9022806910558092808.chunk_text: Image 2: infographic on the benefits of skillsfuture sg https://asktraining.com.sg/wp-content/uploads/2024/07/Benefits-of-SkillsFuture_infographic.png) How to Get Started with SkillsFuture Singapore? Getting started with SSG is easy! Here’s a roadmap for each group: Mid Career Professionals, Young Professionals, and Students:

2-chunk_30_-1815464105209686095.chunk_text: Here’s a roadmap for each group: Mid Career Professionals, Young Professionals, and Students: 1. Register for a MySkillsFuture Account https://www.myskillsfuture.gov.sg/content/portal/en/index.html): This online portal is your one stop access point for everything related to SkillsFuture. Registering is free and allows you to access a wealth of resources, including:

2-chunk_31_-4149341862518182969.chunk_text: Registering is free and allows you to access a wealth of resources, including: Your SkillsFuture Credit balance and expiry details Course listings and programme information tailored to your interests and career goals Eligibility criteria for subsidies and grants

2-chunk_32_-4587946349106451934.chunk_text: Eligibility criteria for subsidies and grants 1. Skills Assessment: MySkillsFuture also offers skills assessments https://www.myskillsfuture.gov.sg/content/portal/en/assessment/landing.html) to help you identify your strengths, weaknesses, and potential skill gaps. This self assessment tool provides valuable insights into areas you might want to focus on for upskilling or reskilling.

2-chunk_33_-7533653184240717936.chunk_text: This self assessment tool provides valuable insights into areas you might want to focus on for upskilling or reskilling. 2. Explore Learning Pathways: With a clear understanding of your skills and career aspirations, browse the extensive list of SkillsFuture approved courses and programmes. https://www.myskillsfuture.gov.sg/content/portal/en/training-exchange/course-landing.html)

2-chunk_34_2025619515622028594.chunk_text: https://www.myskillsfuture.gov.sg/content/portal/en/training-exchange/course-landing.html) You can filter your search by industry, skill set, course format online, in person, blended , and budget to find the perfect fit. We have also compiled a list of SkillsFuture funding and initiatives https://asktraining.com.sg/blog/how-to-take-advantage-of-skillsfuture-courses-for-your-mid-career-switch-in-2024/) as a guide to see which fits you best! Employers and HR Professionals:

2-chunk_35_-2561629280166752519.chunk_text: Employers and HR Professionals: 1. SkillsFuture for Employers Website : This dedicated GoBusiness Singapore https://skillsfuture.gobusiness.gov.sg/) website by SkillsFuture provides comprehensive resources and guidance specifically for businesses looking to leverage SkillsFuture for employee development. 2.

2-chunk_36_-1267991557026661548.chunk_text: 2. Funding and Grants: Explore the various employer and employee training grants available https://skillsfuture.gobusiness.gov.sg/support-and-programmes/funding/training-subsidies-for-employers) to offset the cost of training your workforce. These grants can significantly reduce your investment in employee development programmes. 3.

2-chunk_37_2325258643159968544.chunk_text: 3. Skills Framework for Singapore: This SkillsFuture framework https://www.skillsfuture.gov.sg/initiatives/early-career/skills-framework) outlines the key skills and competencies required for various job roles across different industries. Use this framework to identify skill gaps within your workforce and design targeted training programmes to address them. Wrapping Up

2-chunk_38_7815592320035355321.chunk_text: Wrapping Up SSG presents a valuable opportunity for Singaporeans at all stages of their careers to invest in their personal and professional development. By leveraging the resources and support offered, you can enhance your skillset, boost your career prospects, and contribute to Singapore’s continued economic growth. Take the first step towards your future today!

2-chunk_39_4071682238592343680.chunk_text: Take the first step towards your future today! Visit the official SkillsFuture website https://www.skillsfuture.gov.sg/) to explore the vast range of learning opportunities available! Explore Courses From @ASK Training As a SkillsFuture Singapore appointed Continuing Education and Training Centre CETC , @ASK Training is here to be your partner on your lifelong learning journey.

2-chunk_40_-942937802137573980.chunk_text: As a SkillsFuture Singapore appointed Continuing Education and Training Centre CETC , @ASK Training is here to be your partner on your lifelong learning journey. Here are just a few of the exciting areas we specialise in: Digital Marketing https://asktraining.com.sg/digital-marketing-courses/): Take your digital marketing skills to the next level with courses in social media marketing, search engine optimisation SEO , content marketing, and more. Information Technology IT https://asktraining.com.sg/it-courses/): Whether you’re looking to gain foundational IT skills or advance your expertise in specific areas, we offer courses in cybersecurity, cloud computing, programming languages, and more.

2-chunk_41_-8523204647464828729.chunk_text: Information Technology IT https://asktraining.com.sg/it-courses/): Whether you’re looking to gain foundational IT skills or advance your expertise in specific areas, we offer courses in cybersecurity, cloud computing, programming languages, and more. Microsoft Office https://asktraining.com.sg/microsoft-office-courses/): Master the latest Microsoft Office applications, such as Word, Excel, PowerPoint, and Outlook, to enhance your productivity and efficiency. Soft Skills https://asktraining.com.sg/personal-development-courses/): Develop essential soft skills like communication, teamwork, problem solving, and critical thinking to excel in any work environment. Our dedicated team is here to answer any questions you may have and guide you on your SkillsFuture journey.

3-chunk_0_-4831112836033955989.chunk_text: Title: MNCs in Singapore: Top Companies for Expansion BBCIncorp Singapore URL Source: https://bbcincorp.com/sg/articles/mncs-in-singapore Published Time: 2025 03 19T03:57:01 00:00 Markdown Content:

3-chunk_1_168776789074422772.chunk_text: Markdown Content: Singapore has emerged as a global hub for multinational corporations MNCs , offering a vibrant business environment, world class infrastructure, and strategic location. An MNC in Singapore isn’t just a business entity—it’s a key player in driving the nation’s economic growth and fostering innovation. These companies fuel job creation, support technological advancements, and contribute significantly to Singapore’s global competitiveness.

3-chunk_2_2701406092550548990.chunk_text: These companies fuel job creation, support technological advancements, and contribute significantly to Singapore’s global competitiveness. With their extensive networks and resources, MNCs are transforming industries and shaping the future of the economy. In this blog, we’ll explore the pivotal role of MNCs in Singapore, their impact on the economy, and how they inspire groundbreaking innovation. Overview of MNC in Singapore

3-chunk_3_7747412766623798667.chunk_text: Overview of MNC in Singapore What is MNC in Singapore? A multinational corporation https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multinational_corporation) MNC in Singapore is a large company with operations spanning multiple countries, with a significant presence in the city state. Typically headquartered in another nation, these corporations maintain regional or local offices in Singapore to manage their global activities.

3-chunk_4_2614872803073514975.chunk_text: Typically headquartered in another nation, these corporations maintain regional or local offices in Singapore to manage their global activities. MNCs in Singapore operate across various industries, including technology, food, logistics, and fashion, contributing to the nation’s dynamic economy. The size and influence of MNCs allow them to create numerous employment opportunities and drive economic growth in Singapore. These corporations thrive by leveraging their vast resources, innovation, and commitment to maintaining consistent standards across international markets, benefiting both the MNCs and the local economy.

3-chunk_5_680212582085092690.chunk_text: These corporations thrive by leveraging their vast resources, innovation, and commitment to maintaining consistent standards across international markets, benefiting both the MNCs and the local economy. Impact of MNCs on Singapore’s economy MNCs play a pivotal role in driving Singapore’s economic growth. Their operations create thousands of jobs across various sectors, strengthening the nation’s workforce.

3-chunk_6_8371884875909022121.chunk_text: Their operations create thousands of jobs across various sectors, strengthening the nation’s workforce. Additionally, they attract substantial foreign direct investments FDIs , boosting capital flows and fostering economic stability. By partnering with local small and medium enterprises SMEs , an MNC company in Singapore stimulates business growth and innovation within the local economy. Singapore’s reputation as a global business hub owes much to MNCs, which leverage the city state’s strategic location and infrastructure to access Southeast Asian markets.

3-chunk_7_4117101333562274630.chunk_text: Singapore’s reputation as a global business hub owes much to MNCs, which leverage the city state’s strategic location and infrastructure to access Southeast Asian markets. Their presence not only enhances Singapore’s global business standing but also fosters a culture of innovation, making the country a magnet for cutting edge industries. Why MNCs choose Singapore Singapore’s appeal as a top destination for multinational companies lies in a combination of strategic advantages.

3-chunk_8_1935056809285105218.chunk_text: Singapore’s appeal as a top destination for multinational companies lies in a combination of strategic advantages. The ease of starting and running a business is supported by efficient government processes, ensuring a seamless experience for investors. Complementing this is a robust legal framework and low crime rates, providing businesses with the stability and security essential for sustained success. Situated in the heart of Southeast Asia, Singapore acts as a gateway to emerging markets.

3-chunk_9_7944055199146807992.chunk_text: Situated in the heart of Southeast Asia, Singapore acts as a gateway to emerging markets. Its exceptional logistics infrastructure and extensive air connectivity make operations more efficient, while comprehensive trade agreements reduce barriers to international commerce. Additionally, the city state’s dedication to protecting intellectual property ensures that innovations are well safeguarded, fostering confidence among businesses. Singapore’s vibrant financial ecosystem further enhances its attractiveness.

3-chunk_10_-1429569263345399607.chunk_text: Singapore’s vibrant financial ecosystem further enhances its attractiveness. Companies benefit from easy access to funding and financial services at competitive rates, creating an environment conducive to growth. To entice MNCs, the government offers generous tax incentives and exemptions, encouraging the establishment of regional headquarters. With its stable political climate, unwavering commitment to intellectual property rights, and world class infrastructure, Singapore provides a solid foundation for businesses to thrive.

3-chunk_11_-1346644918565351128.chunk_text: With its stable political climate, unwavering commitment to intellectual property rights, and world class infrastructure, Singapore provides a solid foundation for businesses to thrive. Together, these factors position Singapore as the destination of choice for MNCs looking to expand their global presence. List of multinational companies in Singapore Singapore, a global business hub, hosts numerous multinational corporations across diverse industries, drawn by its strategic location, robust infrastructure, and pro business environment.

3-chunk_12_-8474302163826360051.chunk_text: Singapore, a global business hub, hosts numerous multinational corporations across diverse industries, drawn by its strategic location, robust infrastructure, and pro business environment. Below is a list of multinational companies in Singapore , categorized by industry. 1. Tech and innovation

3-chunk_13_-8577431281293662308.chunk_text: Tech and innovation Singapore’s focus on innovation and technology has attracted leading MNCs that drive advancements in this sector. Companies like 3M , IBM , Micron Semiconductor Asia , Panasonic Asia Pacific , and Schneider Electric leverage Singapore’s strong research ecosystem and skilled talent pool. These MNCs not only enhance the industry but also contribute to building Singapore’s reputation as a regional innovation hub.

3-chunk_14_8242232586394354430.chunk_text: These MNCs not only enhance the industry but also contribute to building Singapore’s reputation as a regional innovation hub. 2. Advisory services The advisory sector thrives in Singapore, with global firms providing essential services to businesses navigating complex markets.

3-chunk_15_-5276886091263608650.chunk_text: The advisory sector thrives in Singapore, with global firms providing essential services to businesses navigating complex markets. Leading names such as Ernst & Young , Accenture , KPMG , Deloitte , and PricewaterhouseCoopers deliver expertise in consulting, auditing, and strategy. These MNCs benefit from Singapore’s stable economy and its position as a gateway to Southeast Asia. 3.

3-chunk_16_-5554215028810877641.chunk_text: 3. Banking Singapore’s banking industry is bolstered by a mix of local and international MNCs. UOB , Citibank , MayBank , OCBC Bank , and Standard Chartered Bank serve as pillars of the financial ecosystem.

3-chunk_17_-4875152714473389808.chunk_text: UOB , Citibank , MayBank , OCBC Bank , and Standard Chartered Bank serve as pillars of the financial ecosystem. These banks are drawn to Singapore for its regulatory efficiency, financial stability, and role as a global wealth management hub. 4. Energy & industrial

3-chunk_18_9191289308108141803.chunk_text: Energy & industrial In the energy and industrial sectors, major players like ExxonMobil , Shell , General Electric , Siemens , Caterpillar , and Sembcorp are integral to Singapore’s industrial growth. These companies are attracted by Singapore’s advanced logistics capabilities and its position as a regional energy hub. 5.

3-chunk_19_463445200536072818.chunk_text: 5. Consumer goods and retail MNC companies in Singapore like Procter & Gamble, Fraser & Neave, McDonald’s, Kentucky Fried Chicken, and Dairy Farm International dominate Singapore’s consumer goods and retail sector. Their presence is supported by Singapore’s vibrant consumer market and efficient supply chain infrastructure.

3-chunk_20_-8412266648346729191.chunk_text: Their presence is supported by Singapore’s vibrant consumer market and efficient supply chain infrastructure. 6. Healthcare & pharmaceuticals Singapore is a key hub for healthcare and pharmaceutical MNCs, including GlaxoSmithKline, Johnson & Johnson, Medtronic, and Novartis.

3-chunk_21_6197778632160407236.chunk_text: Singapore is a key hub for healthcare and pharmaceutical MNCs, including GlaxoSmithKline, Johnson & Johnson, Medtronic, and Novartis. These firms capitalize on the country’s strong intellectual property protection and access to regional markets. 7. Real estate & hospitality

3-chunk_22_-959228030784938655.chunk_text: Real estate & hospitality The real estate and hospitality sectors are powered by MNCs such as Far East Organization, MapleTree Group, CapitaLand, Marina Bay Sands, and InterContinental Hotels Group. Singapore’s reputation as a global tourism and business destination makes it an ideal base for these companies. What to consider before establishing an MNC in Singapore

3-chunk_23_258464828947525374.chunk_text: What to consider before establishing an MNC in Singapore Legal considerations Understanding and adhering to Singapore’s legal requirements is crucial for businesses seeking to establish themselves in the region. All companies must register with the Accounting and Corporate Regulatory Authority ACRA , adhering to several key requirements:

3-chunk_24_8094892568262728339.chunk_text: All companies must register with the Accounting and Corporate Regulatory Authority ACRA , adhering to several key requirements: At least one director must be a Singapore resident, such as a citizen or Employment Pass holder. Companies must appoint a local company secretary within six months of incorporation. A physical Singapore address is mandatory for the company’s registered office.

3-chunk_25_-4448442241692361449.chunk_text: A physical Singapore address is mandatory for the company’s registered office. Additionally, while the minimum paid up capital for most companies is just SGD 1, certain sectors require higher amounts. For instance, insurance intermediary firms must have a minimum paid up capital of SGD 300,000. By partnering with a corporate service provider, like BBCIncorp, MNCs can navigate these requirements seamlessly, laying a solid legal foundation for operations in Singapore and across Asia.

3-chunk_26_-2570367144916906855.chunk_text: By partnering with a corporate service provider, like BBCIncorp, MNCs can navigate these requirements seamlessly, laying a solid legal foundation for operations in Singapore and across Asia. These services ensure compliance, mitigate risks, and provide ongoing support, allowing businesses to focus on growth. Logistical and strategic planning Setting up operations in Singapore demands careful logistical and strategic planning.

3-chunk_27_5644237385172314476.chunk_text: Setting up operations in Singapore demands careful logistical and strategic planning. 4-chunk_2_3821439496698198641.chunk_text: The Merlion of Singapore > On Singapore's Economic Miracle: "Singapore was thrown out of the Malaysian Federation in 1965. Within a very short period of time, largely because of the use of English common law and other regulatory advantages over the surrounding area, Singapore became a powerful economic engine. In fact, right now Singapore is one of the top six cities in the world....

4-chunk_3_8397073703664313411.chunk_text:
In fact, right now Singapore is one of the top six cities in the world.... These cities are governed by regulatory systems that deliver open trade, property rights protection, the rule of law and merit based competition that creates an environment where insurgent companies can actually be successful. There is nothing in the way of an entrepreneur’s vision and dreams. > Shanker Singham

4-chunk_7_-5608447689373757513.chunk_text: Starting with their 1965 separation from the Malaysian Federation, Singapore faced on their own, the daunting task of replacing their role as the transshipment point and major naval base for the British Empire in Southeast Asia. They chose to establish themselves as an independent economic force, and in an entirely new national direction. S ingapore’s Stages of Economic Development Between the 1960’s and the 2000’s, Singapore went through the following phases: Labor intensive, skill intensive, capital intensive, technology intensive, and, finally, innovation intensive.

4-chunk_8_-1895184942400378741.chunk_text:
Between the 1960’s and the 2000’s, Singapore went through the following phases: Labor intensive, skill intensive, capital intensive, technology intensive, and, finally, innovation intensive. See the IMF study Breaking the Oil Spell: The Gulf Falcons’ Path to Diversification, Chapter 3 https://www.elibrary.imf.org/display/book/9781513537863/ch004.xml), entitled “Going Beyond Comparative Advantage: How Singapore Did It” by Phillip Yeo. Income per capita went from $428 per year to $54,000 per year US dollars . In 2022, Singapore’s per capita income was $83,000.

4-chunk_10_6243914082436446719.chunk_text: By the 1970’s, manufacturing had become a significant percentage of Singapore’s GDP, which was an initial crucial step away from their previous existence as a British outpost. The Singapore government’s role in this development was, of course, significant in these early stages. The land was developed to establish areas suitable for industry and manufacturing, and this included the improvement of internal waterways. Housing and health care were provided for the population.

4-chunk_11_-7263672895032329213.chunk_text: Housing and health care were provided for the population. Singapore’s government also played a major role in the education system, which was crucial for the nation to move forward towards greater skill sets and innovation. Looking to the outside world, Singapore’s leaders realized they needed to attract foreign investment, which they accomplished with great success. Electronics and computer parts, including software and chips, were amongst some of the types of companies which established facilities in Singapore.

4-chunk_12_-1914150408659096501.chunk_text: Electronics and computer parts, including software and chips, were amongst some of the types of companies which established facilities in Singapore. In 1969, Texas Instruments opened a plant in Singapore, beginning a flood of foreign investment. Singapore, with the collaboration of foreign nations and multi national corporations, established training centers in order to upgrade the skill level of its citizens. But, as is typical in Singapore’s free market thinking, the nation also adopted a liberal policy towards immigration of highly skilled foreign nationals in order to fill the gap of needed expertise.

4-chunk_13_4521834998318970065.chunk_text: But, as is typical in Singapore’s free market thinking, the nation also adopted a liberal policy towards immigration of highly skilled foreign nationals in order to fill the gap of needed expertise. Contrary to various prejudices against “cheap foreign labor”, in the 1980’s Singapore embarked upon its “Second Industrial Revolution” – the push towards capital intensive industries. By the 90’s, Singapore set its sights on becoming a “first world” nation in every respect. This included a shift towards knowledge and innovation.

4-chunk_14_-6962727262152832753.chunk_text: This included a shift towards knowledge and innovation. This was fully accomplished in the 2000’s. Today, Singapore is a fully diversified and forward driven nation. See chart summarizing GNP by sector.

4-chunk_27_5855554949692614777.chunk_text: Competition within the Border The government of Singapore has been increasing its commitment to an innovation based economy, which is focused on growing its domestic start ups based largely upon new technology. Singapore provides an excellent environment for establishing such domestic enterprise by its investment in the quality of education and workforce development. Venture funds have been aided by the government, providing support for new ventures and scaling them upwards.

4-chunk_28_232698784203587414.chunk_text: Venture funds have been aided by the government, providing support for new ventures and scaling them upwards. Singapore’s extraordinary infrastructure includes cutting edge development around green technology, smart city technology, and water management. By setting benchmark goals in these areas, local innovation based upon competition is fostered. Open Trade

4-chunk_29_-7749262448902439571.chunk_text: Open Trade Ranks number one in the Heritage Foundation’s 2023 “Index of Economic Freedom. ” https://www.heritage.org/index/country/singapore) That report states: “The trade regime is open and competitive, and no tariffs are imposed on imports. The law treats foreign and domestic businesses equally, and nearly all sectors of the economy are open to 100 percent foreign ownership.

4-chunk_30_5614394980869249597.chunk_text: The law treats foreign and domestic businesses equally, and nearly all sectors of the economy are open to 100 percent foreign ownership. The financial sector is highly competitive and resilient. More than 25 Free Trade Agreements. 4-chunk_31_6163507421001208911.chunk_text: Hosts ” a diverse group of shipping companies providing a wide spectrum of maritime services such as ship management, ship agency, broking, finance, insurance, legal and arbitration, survey, and research and development” says Lim. Streamlined business regulations with low tax rates.

The second busiest port in the world, connected to 600 ports and with 130,000 vessels docking every year.

The term is ultimately derived from Greek https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Greek_language "Greek language" οἰκονομία https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%CE%BF%E1%BC%B0%CE%BA%CE%BF%CE%BD%CE%BF%CE%BC%CE%AF%CE%B1#Ancient_Greek "wikt:οἰκονομία" , from οἶκος https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%CE%BF%E1%BC%B6%CE%BA%CE%BF%CF%82#Ancient_Greek "wikt:οἶκος" , "house", and νέμω https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%CE%BD%CE%AD%CE%BC%CF%89#Ancient_Greek "wikt:νέμω" , "to manage".

6-chunk_55_-6611109615622897537.chunk_text: The term is ultimately derived from Greek https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Greek_language "Greek language" οἰκονομία https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%CE%BF%E1%BC%B0%CE%BA%CE%BF%CE%BD%CE%BF%CE%BC%CE%AF%CE%B1#Ancient_Greek "wikt:οἰκονομία" , from οἶκος https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%CE%BF%E1%BC%B6%CE%BA%CE%BF%CF%82#Ancient_Greek "wikt:οἶκος" , "house", and νέμω https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%CE%BD%CE%AD%CE%BC%CF%89#Ancient_Greek "wikt:νέμω" , "to manage". In contemporary times, however, the spelling that begins with œ has become obsolete and rarely used, since it has been reduced to e in American English or separated as oe in British English https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/American_and_British_English_spelling_differences#ae_and_oe "American and British English spelling differences" . From the eighteenth century, the spelling oeconomy dropped the letter o , thus making economy the common spelling for the term. 1 https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Economy cite note 1 2 https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Economy cite note 2

Singapore's economy is often referred to as a "miracle" due to its rapid transformation from a developing country to a developed, high income economy in a relatively short period of time. This transformation took place in the second half of the 20th century under the leadership of Prime Minister Lee Kuan Yew and his government.

8-chunk_66_5686693195150899940.chunk_text: This transformation took place in the second half of the 20th century under the leadership of Prime Minister Lee Kuan Yew and his government. 36 https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Economy_of_Singapore cite note 39 One of the key factors contributing to Singapore's economic miracle was its strategic location, which made it an ideal hub for international trade and commerce. 37 https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Economy_of_Singapore cite note 40 The country's main exports include electronics https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Electronics "Electronics" , chemicals https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chemical "Chemical" and services https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Service_(economics) "Service economics " .

8-chunk_122_2779899807367018581.chunk_text: Government linked corporations play a substantial role in Singapore's domestic economy. As of November 2011, the top six Singapore listed GLCs accounted for about 17 percent of total capitalization of the Singapore Exchange SGX . 8-chunk_171_-4350856584192905689.chunk_text: Singapore workforce edit https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Economy_of_Singapore&action=edit&section=19 "Edit section: Singapore workforce" In 2000, Singapore had a workforce of about 2. 2 million.

8-chunk_172_-453485714088259765.chunk_text: 2 million. With limited access to natural resources, Singapore had been forced to invest in its people. citation needed https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation\ needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed" The country has the largest proficiency of English language speakers in Asia, making it an attractive place for multinational corporations. Singapore has come a long way from where it once stood.

8-chunk_173_6134396632327322787.chunk_text: Singapore has come a long way from where it once stood. In the 1970s according to Tilak Abeysinghe "2. 4 percent of the labor force were degree holders". By 1990 the number rose to just 6.

8-chunk_174_6047454996994864049.chunk_text: By 1990 the number rose to just 6. 3%. In 2013 the percentage of the labor force who held degrees reached 31%. The nation's directive toward high skilled labor jobs, has promoted both growth and education to the region.

8-chunk_175_-2717016717325311252.chunk_text: The nation's directive toward high skilled labor jobs, has promoted both growth and education to the region. 120 https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Economy_of_Singapore cite note 123 The National Trades Union Congress https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Trades_Union_Congress "National Trades Union Congress" NTUC , the sole trade union federation, which has a symbiotic relationship with the ruling party, accounts for almost 99% of total organised labour. Government policy and pro activity rather than labour legislation controls general labour and trade union matters. citation needed https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation\ needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed"

8-chunk_176_3727792230124952660.chunk_text: citation needed https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation\ needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed" The Employment Act offers little protection to white collar workers due to an income threshold. The Industrial Arbitration Court handles labour management disputes that cannot be resolved informally through the Ministry of Manpower. The Singapore Government https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Singapore Government "Singapore Government" has stressed the importance of co operation between unions, management and government tripartism https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tripartism "Tripartism" , as well as the early resolution of disputes.

8-chunk_177_6930133220218900986.chunk_text: The Singapore Government https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Singapore Government "Singapore Government" has stressed the importance of co operation between unions, management and government tripartism https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tripartism "Tripartism" , as well as the early resolution of disputes. There has been only one strike in the past 15 years. Singapore has enjoyed virtually full employment for long periods of time. Amid an economic slump, the unemployment rate rose to 4.

8-chunk_178_5476270546540436886.chunk_text: Amid an economic slump, the unemployment rate rose to 4. 0% by the end of 2001, from 2. 4% early in the year. Unemployment has since declined and as of 2012 the unemployment rate stands at 1.

8-chunk_179_-3925992985452295968.chunk_text: Unemployment has since declined and as of 2012 the unemployment rate stands at 1. 9%. 121 https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Economy_of_Singapore cite note 124 While the Singapore government has taken a stance against minimum wage https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Minimum_wage "Minimum wage" and unemployment benefit https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unemployment_benefit "Unemployment benefit" schemes, in 2007 the government introduced a Workfare Income Supplement WIS scheme to supplement wages of low skilled workers.

8-chunk_180_-813106193391901362.chunk_text: While the Singapore government has taken a stance against minimum wage https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Minimum_wage "Minimum wage" and unemployment benefit https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unemployment_benefit "Unemployment benefit" schemes, in 2007 the government introduced a Workfare Income Supplement WIS scheme to supplement wages of low skilled workers. 122 https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Economy_of_Singapore cite note Workfare 125 To support employers in hiring older Singaporean workers, Special Employment Credit SEC was introduced in 2011. It was first enhanced in 2012 to provide employers with support in hiring older Singaporean workers and Persons with Disabilities PWDs . It helped the employers to cope with costs associated with the increase in Central Provident Fund CPF contribution rates for older workers.

8-chunk_181_-7344138414810723230.chunk_text: It helped the employers to cope with costs associated with the increase in Central Provident Fund CPF contribution rates for older workers. The 5 year SEC scheme was further extended an additional 3 years, up to 2019 to encourage employers to voluntarily re employ older workers aged 65 and above. 123 https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Economy_of_Singapore cite note 126 The Singapore Government and the NTUC have tried a range of programs to increase lagging productivity and boost the labour force participation rates of women and older workers. However, labour shortages persist in the service sector and in many low skilled positions in the construction and electronics industries.

8-chunk_182_3854814530851087004.chunk_text: However, labour shortages persist in the service sector and in many low skilled positions in the construction and electronics industries. Foreign workers help make up this shortfall. In 2000, there were about 600,000 foreign workers in Singapore, constituting 27% of the total work force. As a result, wages are relatively suppressed or do not rise for all workers.

8-chunk_183_4382984816930163167.chunk_text: As a result, wages are relatively suppressed or do not rise for all workers. To have some controls, the government imposes a foreign worker levy payable by employers for low end workers like domestic help and construction workers. 124 https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Economy_of_Singapore cite note 127 In 2012, the Ministry of Trade and Industry MTI reported that Singapore should continue to fine tune the calibration of its inflow of foreigners as the country continues to face an ageing population and a shrinking workforce. Singapore Parliament accepted the recommendations by its Economic Strategies Committee ESC for the optimal ratio of the level of immigration and foreign manpower for both high and low skilled workers.

8-chunk_184_7163118091170789113.chunk_text: Singapore Parliament accepted the recommendations by its Economic Strategies Committee ESC for the optimal ratio of the level of immigration and foreign manpower for both high and low skilled workers. 125 https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Economy_of_Singapore cite note 128 The Government recognises that the current overall foreign workforce should complement the local resident workforce and not replace the Singaporean Core concept, and helps companies greatly as they raise productivity through business restructuring and workforce retraining; raise resident labour force participation rate. 126 https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Economy_of_Singapore cite note 129 127 https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Economy_of_Singapore cite note 130 Poverty and economic inequality

8-chunk_185_-8076837411531624620.chunk_text: Poverty and economic inequality edit https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Economy_of_Singapore&action=edit&section=20 "Edit section: Poverty and economic inequality" Singapore is one of the world's wealthiest countries per capita , but its Gini coefficient https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gini_coefficient "Gini coefficient" is high in comparison to developed countries. Statistics on income inequality are published by the Singapore Department of Statistics.

8-chunk_186_-8601429565134151561.chunk_text: Statistics on income inequality are published by the Singapore Department of Statistics. 128 https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Economy_of_Singapore cite note 131 Without taking taxes and social transfers into account, Singapore's gini coefficient https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gini_coefficient "Gini coefficient" puts the country in the medium range. Nevertheless, the country remains on the "very high" category on the inequality adjusted human development index IHDI , a ranking similar to the Human Development Index https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human_Development_Index "Human Development Index" HDI , but with inequality https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Economic_inequality "Economic inequality" also accounted for. 129 https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Economy_of_Singapore cite note IHDI 132

8-chunk_187_7187996219518217656.chunk_text: 129 https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Economy_of_Singapore cite note IHDI 132 In October 2018, Oxfam https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Oxfam "Oxfam" ranked Singapore 149 out of 157 in its Commitment to Reducing Inequality Index 2018, placing it among the bottom ten of the countries in the index, which ranks countries based on efforts to reduce economic inequality https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Economic_inequality "Economic inequality" . 130 https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Economy_of_Singapore cite note oxfam inequality 133 In its report, Oxfam accused Singapore of practices which encouraged "harmful tax practices", not having a universal minimum wage https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Minimum_wage "Minimum wage" apart from janitors https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Janitor "Janitor" and security guards , and poor performance on labour rights https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Labour_rights "Labour rights" . 131 https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Economy_of_Singapore cite note 134 The government responded to the report by claiming that it was more important to look at "real outcomes" such as Singapore's high home ownership, health, education, and employment, rather than public spending or tax rates, also saying that the report "assumes that high taxation and high public expenditure reflects commitment to combating inequality".

8-chunk_188_-7219227276320423328.chunk_text: 131 https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Economy_of_Singapore cite note 134 The government responded to the report by claiming that it was more important to look at "real outcomes" such as Singapore's high home ownership, health, education, and employment, rather than public spending or tax rates, also saying that the report "assumes that high taxation and high public expenditure reflects commitment to combating inequality". 130 https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Economy_of_Singapore cite note oxfam inequality 133 The government provides social support through a variety of social assistance schemes. The Ministry of Social and Family Development https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ministry_of_Social_and_Family_Development "Ministry of Social and Family Development" runs ComCare, a program which provides income support for low income citizen households through various schemes for short to medium term assistance, long term assistance, child support, and urgent financial needs.

8-chunk_189_-7261780781516397878.chunk_text: The Ministry of Social and Family Development https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ministry_of_Social_and_Family_Development "Ministry of Social and Family Development" runs ComCare, a program which provides income support for low income citizen households through various schemes for short to medium term assistance, long term assistance, child support, and urgent financial needs. 132 https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Economy_of_Singapore cite note 135 The Community Development Councils https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Community_Development_Council "Community Development Council" also run various local assistance schemes within their districts. 133 https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Economy_of_Singapore cite note 136 The Ministry of Manpower https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ministry_of_Manpower_(Singapore) "Ministry of Manpower Singapore " runs a Silver Support Scheme which provides additional financial support for low income elderly with no family support. 134 https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Economy_of_Singapore cite note 137 Meanwhile, the Ministry of Health https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ministry_of_Health_(Singapore) "Ministry of Health Singapore " also runs MediFund to assist families that have difficulty paying for medical bills despite government subsidies and other health financing schemes https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Healthcare_in_Singapore "Healthcare in Singapore" .

8-chunk_200_-165418004780496968.chunk_text: The Monetary Authority of Singapore https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Monetary_Authority_of_Singapore "Monetary Authority of Singapore" MAS is Singapore's central bank https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Central_bank "Central bank" and financial regulatory https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Financial_regulation "Financial regulation" authority. Its current chairman is Lawrence Wong https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lawrence_Wong "Lawrence Wong" July 2023–present . 158 https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Economy_of_Singapore cite note 161 It administers the various statutes pertaining to money, banking, insurance, securities and the financial sector in general, as well as currency issuance https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Singapore_dollar "Singapore dollar" . The MAS has been given powers to act as a banker to and financial agent of the Government.

8-chunk_201_6062930951624923914.chunk_text: The MAS has been given powers to act as a banker to and financial agent of the Government. It has also been entrusted to promote monetary stability, and credit and exchange policies conducive to the growth of the economy. Unlike many other central banks such as Federal Reserve System https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Federal_Reserve_System "Federal Reserve System" , European Central Bank https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/European Central Bank "European Central Bank" or Bank of England https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_England "Bank of England" , MAS does not regulate the monetary system via interest rates to influence the liquidity in the system. Instead, it chooses to do it via the foreign exchange mechanism, which it has been doing since 1981.

8-chunk_202_-5801180569817826825.chunk_text: Instead, it chooses to do it via the foreign exchange mechanism, which it has been doing since 1981. In doing so it manages the Singapore dollar versus a number of currencies that they do not reveal publicly – a Singapore dollar nominal effective exchange rate S$ NEER . It carries this out by intervening in the SGD market as well as other operations in the money market. 159 https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Economy_of_Singapore cite note 162 160 https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Economy_of_Singapore cite note 163 The MAS reviews its policy stance less frequently than most central banks, in a cycle that is around every 6 months.

It was subsequently raised in January 2013 and then again in July 2018.

8-chunk_217_3630277403272296456.chunk_text: It was subsequently raised in January 2013 and then again in July 2018. Currently for Singapore citizens buying their first property, there is no ABSD. For their second property onwards, they pay up to 15% ABSD. For foreigners the ABSD rate is 60% no matter if it is the first property.

8-chunk_218_1725772817264023591.chunk_text: For foreigners the ABSD rate is 60% no matter if it is the first property. And for entities it is 65%. 179 https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Economy_of_Singapore cite note 182 At the same time they raised the ABSD in 2018, the MAS tightened rules on housing loans, by limiting the loan tenure and reducing the Loan to Value ratio. 180 https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Economy_of_Singapore cite note 183 181 https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Economy_of_Singapore cite note 184

11-chunk_9_8929019785803908027.chunk_text: gov. mo https://www.dsec.gov.mo/BayArea/en-US/) The Guangdong–Hong Kong–Macao Greater Bay Area , 2 https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Guangdong%E2%80%93Hong_Kong%E2%80%93Macao_Greater_Bay_Area cite note 2 a https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Guangdong%E2%80%93Hong_Kong%E2%80%93Macao_Greater_Bay_Area cite note 3 commonly referred to as the Greater Bay Area GBA , is a megalopolis https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Megalopolis "Megalopolis" , consisting of nine cities and two special administrative regions https://en.wikipedia. It is envisioned by Chinese government planners as an integrated economic area aimed at taking a leading role globally by 2035.

11-chunk_10_-6720062192680160556.chunk_text: It is envisioned by Chinese government planners as an integrated economic area aimed at taking a leading role globally by 2035. 3 https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Guangdong%E2%80%93Hong_Kong%E2%80%93Macao_Greater_Bay_Area cite note 4 4 https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Guangdong%E2%80%93Hong_Kong%E2%80%93Macao_Greater_Bay_Area cite note 5 It is the largest and most populated urban area in the world. 5 https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Guangdong%E2%80%93Hong_Kong%E2%80%93Macao_Greater_Bay_Area cite note Statista 6 The GBA—with a total population of approximately 86 million people—includes nine mega cities https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Megacity "Megacity" of Guangdong province https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Guangdong "Guangdong" : Guangzhou https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Guangzhou "Guangzhou" , Shenzhen https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shenzhen "Shenzhen" , Zhuhai https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zhuhai "Zhuhai" , Foshan https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Foshan "Foshan" , Dongguan https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dongguan "Dongguan" , Zhongshan https://en.wikipedia.

11-chunk_11_-8703204733875850982.chunk_text: 5 https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Guangdong%E2%80%93Hong_Kong%E2%80%93Macao_Greater_Bay_Area cite note Statista 6 The GBA—with a total population of approximately 86 million people—includes nine mega cities https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Megacity "Megacity" of Guangdong province https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Guangdong "Guangdong" : Guangzhou https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Guangzhou "Guangzhou" , Shenzhen https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shenzhen "Shenzhen" , Zhuhai https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zhuhai "Zhuhai" , Foshan https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Foshan "Foshan" , Dongguan https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dongguan "Dongguan" , Zhongshan https://en.wikipedia. Hong Kong, Guangzhou, and Shenzhen have been described among the world's 50 "superstar cities". 6 https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Guangdong%E2%80%93Hong_Kong%E2%80%93Macao_Greater_Bay_Area cite note 7 Surrounding the Pearl River Delta https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pearl_River_Delta "Pearl River Delta" with a total area of 56,000 km 2 comparable in size to Croatia https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Croatia "Croatia" , it is the largest and the richest economic region in South China https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/South_China "South China" . The GBA's combined regional GDP https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gross_domestic_product "Gross domestic product" was RMB¥13 trillion US$1.

11-chunk_12_1275766809196359864.chunk_text: The GBA's combined regional GDP https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gross_domestic_product "Gross domestic product" was RMB¥13 trillion US$1. 8 trillion in 2022, which was equivalent to over 10 percent of GDP for all of China. As one of China's most vibrant and important regions, the GBA has the highest concentration of Fortune 500 companies https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fortune_Global_500 "Fortune Global 500" in the country and houses a majority of China's most innovative technology companies, such as Huawei https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Huawei "Huawei" , ZTE https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ZTE "ZTE" , DJI https://en.wikipedia. GBA has a rich ecosystem of startups, incubators, and accelerators in the fields of agile tech, biotech, medical tech, and innovation https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Innovation "Innovation" .

11-chunk_13_-5829955977148634062.chunk_text: GBA has a rich ecosystem of startups, incubators, and accelerators in the fields of agile tech, biotech, medical tech, and innovation https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Innovation "Innovation" . For these reasons, many experts consider the region an emerging Silicon Valley https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Silicon_Valley "Silicon Valley" of Asia. 7 https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Guangdong%E2%80%93Hong_Kong%E2%80%93Macao_Greater_Bay_Area cite note 8 Given traditional divisions between the provincial and municipal governments and business elites, there are some opinions that the ambitious idea behind the GBA might be difficult to implement. 8 https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Guangdong%E2%80%93Hong_Kong%E2%80%93Macao_Greater_Bay_Area cite note 9

11-chunk_14_8878190927145907325.chunk_text: 8 https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Guangdong%E2%80%93Hong_Kong%E2%80%93Macao_Greater_Bay_Area cite note 9 The "Guangdong–Hong Kong–Macao Greater Bay Area" is sometimes confused with the area of the Pearl River Delta https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pearl_River_Delta "Pearl River Delta" , which is a term coined in 1947 referring to a smaller area. 9 https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Guangdong%E2%80%93Hong_Kong%E2%80%93Macao_Greater_Bay_Area cite note beltandroad. hktdc.

11-chunk_15_1808532183550369222.chunk_text: hktdc. com 10 In the early 2000s, Chinese scholars began using the term “Greater Pearl River Delta” GPRD which described the 9 2 city agglomeration that encompassed post handover Hong Kong and Macao, conceptualized as a series of lesser cities as industrial nodes with specialist functions clustering around two prominent cores – Guangzhou and Shenzhen. In 2003, the province advocated the idea of “Pan PRD” as an even more extensive regional construct that comprised nine neighboring provinces to promote economic cooperation. 10 https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Guangdong%E2%80%93Hong_Kong%E2%80%93Macao_Greater_Bay_Area cite note archdaily.

11-chunk_16_9150654570768445660.chunk_text: 10 https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Guangdong%E2%80%93Hong_Kong%E2%80%93Macao_Greater_Bay_Area cite note archdaily. com 11 A somewhat similar idea is later mentioned in the English version of China's 13th Five Year Plan https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Five-year_plans_of_China#Thirteenth_Plan_(2016%E2%80%932020) "Five year plans of China" , taking the Pearl River Delta and including the larger province of Guangdong. 11 https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Guangdong%E2%80%93Hong_Kong%E2%80%93Macao_Greater_Bay_Area cite note 12 On 1 July 2017, the "Framework Agreement on Deepening Guangdong–Hong Kong–Macao Cooperation in the Development of the Bay Area" 深化粵港澳合作 推進大灣區建設框架協議 was signed in Hong Kong https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hong_Kong "Hong Kong" . 12 https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Guangdong%E2%80%93Hong_Kong%E2%80%93Macao_Greater_Bay_Area cite note 13

11-chunk_17_-3307578659641542292.chunk_text: 12 https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Guangdong%E2%80%93Hong_Kong%E2%80%93Macao_Greater_Bay_Area cite note 13 The Greater Bay Area has been influenced by its coastal location for centuries. The first known ships from the area are believed to have been constructed by the people of the Nanyue Kingdom https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nanyue "Nanyue" 204–112 BCE , who employed them for cultural and economic exchanges with countries as far as present day Vietnam. After the takeover of the Han Dynasty, trading relations expanded beyond to reach Sri Lanka.

11-chunk_18_-8545539635678062285.chunk_text: After the takeover of the Han Dynasty, trading relations expanded beyond to reach Sri Lanka. During the subsequent period of the Three Kingdoms https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Three_Kingdoms "Three Kingdoms" , these trade routes were consolidated. Trade and cultural exchanges grew. Among this, the port of Guangzhou played a major role for the region's trade and cultural exchanges for over two thousand years.

11-chunk_19_-3606555319487347036.chunk_text: Among this, the port of Guangzhou played a major role for the region's trade and cultural exchanges for over two thousand years. Established under the Kingdom of Wu during the period of the Three Kingdoms 222–280 CE , it eventually grew to become the starting point of the ancient maritime silk road during the Eastern Jin Dynasty https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eastern_Jin_Dynasty "Eastern Jin Dynasty" 317–420 CE . By the fourth century CE, communities of foreign merchants began establishing themselves in the city. 13 https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Guangdong%E2%80%93Hong_Kong%E2%80%93Macao_Greater_Bay_Area cite note 14

11-chunk_20_-3511574235572492927.chunk_text: 13 https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Guangdong%E2%80%93Hong_Kong%E2%80%93Macao_Greater_Bay_Area cite note 14 Since the first foreign merchants have established themselves in Guangdong, the whole GBA region's importance for global trade has only increased. When Macao became a Portuguese colony https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Colony "Colony" in the mid 1550s, it represented one of the first trading ports in the Far East. It was later joined by Guangzhou, whose port was the only one remaining open for foreign trade during the closure of the country under the Qing https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Qing_dynasty "Qing dynasty" .

11-chunk_21_6401859696760419667.chunk_text: It was later joined by Guangzhou, whose port was the only one remaining open for foreign trade during the closure of the country under the Qing https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Qing_dynasty "Qing dynasty" . The Opium Wars https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Opium_Wars "Opium Wars" brought Hong Kong under British control and forced the opening of other ports in the region. While their respective economic importance was subject to fluctuations later on, the establishment of special economic zones should begin to drive their economic importance anew. 14 https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Guangdong%E2%80%93Hong_Kong%E2%80%93Macao_Greater_Bay_Area cite note 15

11-chunk_22_-5298962160957649521.chunk_text: 14 https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Guangdong%E2%80%93Hong_Kong%E2%80%93Macao_Greater_Bay_Area cite note 15 Guangzhou https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Guangzhou "Guangzhou" , the provincial capital of Guangdong province https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Guangdong "Guangdong" , attracted the first U. S. investments such as Coca Cola https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Coca-Cola "Coca Cola" , Procter & Gamble https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Procter_%26_Gamble "Procter & Gamble" , Pepsi https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PepsiCo "PepsiCo" in 1990s and to date is the most concentrated area of U.
